context.note: This section is for Eucalyptus HA. If you are not using HA, skip this section.
context.p: Before you begin, ensure that you have the following information:

ul.li: The IP address and hostname of each Walrus
The DRBD block device name of each Walrus. In the following examples, we assume that DRBD block device name is /dev/drbd1.
The DRBD backing disk partition names on each Walrus. A partition (either on a new disk or an existing disk) should be dedicated to Walrus. The partition sizes should be identical.

context.note: Consider backing the DRBD resource with a logical volume using LVM, this will make growing the backing store easier in the future if you are running low on disk space.
context.p: Configuring DRBD requires that you edit the Eucalyptus DRBD file to include your Walrus information, and edit the master DRBD file to tell it to look for the Eucalyptus DRBD file.

step.cmd: Log in to the primary Walrus.

step.stepresult: There is no output from this command.

step.cmd: Copy the example Eucalyptus DRBD file (/etc/eucalyptus/drbd.conf.example) to /etc/eucalyptus/drbd.conf.
Open the /etc/eucalyptus/drbd.conf file and make the following edits:

ul.li: Change the value of <walrus-host-1> to the hostname (output of `uname -n`) of the primary Walrus.
Change the value of <drbd-block-dev, e.g., /dev/drbd1> to /dev/drbd1
Change the value of <drbd-backing-disk-dev, e.g. /dev/sdb1> to /dev/sdb1
Change the value of <walrus-host-1-ip> to the IP address of the primary Walrus.
Change the value of <walrus-host-2> to the hostname (output of `uname -n`) of the secondary Walrus.
Change the value of <drbd-block-dev, e.g., /dev/drbd1> to /dev/drbd1
Change the value of <drbd-backing-disk-dev, e.g. /dev/sdb1> to /dev/sdb1
Change the value of <walrus-host-2-ip> to the IP address of the secondary Walrus.

Copy the /etc/drbd.conf, the /etc/eucalyptus/drbd.conf, and the /etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf files to the secondary Walrus server.

Restart Walrus, first on the primary, and then on the secondary. Restarting the primary Walrus will trigger an HA failover to the secondary, and restarting the secondary will fail back, preparing the entire system for the next steps.
On the primary Walrus, associate the DRBD block device (/dev/drbd1) with the disk partition allocated for Walrus (/dev/sdb1).
